div.p: To this, I replied briefly: Since he himself considered it improper to ask, I could not advise him to do the improper, and even if I did advise it, he would not be at peace in his mind because of it.

However, if it is so that the deceased lords and the bailiff have promised to remember his work, as his work has been commendable so far, he might remind the bailiff, as a friendly man, of the promise with modest words, in good hope of enjoying it.
He, the bailiff, knows well what our lords' order is, against which it would not be proper for Mr. Hansen to act. And if this is done with modesty, I consider it harmless for him.

I do not know of better advice at this time; I write briefly at 9 at night, as I would rather have gone to my rest, since the letter only reached me then and the messenger wanted to leave during the day, etc.
